Fast-forward six months, and on October 08, 2013, Ã¢â‚¬ËœCommon CourtesyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ hit inboxes across the globe (at precisely 5.37am if you want to be picky). After a few listens, there could be no clearer message than this: A Day To Remember are anything but done.

ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s unmistakably the Ã¢â‚¬ËœAll I WantÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ of Ã¢â‚¬ËœCommon CourtesyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, and that Ã¢â‚¬Å“BRACE FOR IMPACT!Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ mosh call is going to set venues alight once everyoneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s got the words down.

ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s also the first point where his thinly-veiled digs at the label that almost didnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t let this record happen come to light Ã¢â‚¬â€œ interpret it how you want, but lines like Ã¢â‚¬Å“God help those who help themselves, and forget about everyone else,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ or Ã¢â‚¬Å“YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re all about you, and itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s my fast track to an early grave,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ later on in Ã¢â‚¬ËœThe Document Speaks For ItselfÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, say everything necessary.

Interestingly, the pace is broken up by a couple of slower numbers this time around Ã¢â‚¬â€œ the acoustic led Ã¢â‚¬ËœIÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m Already GoneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is well-aligned ahead of the scathing Ã¢â‚¬ËœViolence (Enough Is Enough)Ã¢â‚¬â„¢, and later, Ã¢â‚¬ËœI SurrenderÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ dishes out *feelings* left, right and centre, before the abrasive Ã¢â‚¬ËœLife Lessons Learned The Hard WayÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ hits back with full force. While ADTR have always excelled when taking the softer approach (see Ã¢â‚¬ËœIf It Means A Lot To YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ from Ã¢â‚¬ËœHomesickÃ¢â‚¬â„¢), this is the first time theyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve incorporated that corner of their sound into the thread of an albumÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s structure, and it works. As a result, Ã¢â‚¬ËœCommon CourtesyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t just a relentless onslaught of breakdowns and choruses; itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s got defined peaks and troughs that should shut the mouths of anyone whoÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s ever doubted their malleability.

WhatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been most exciting for us with Ã¢â‚¬ËœCommon CourtesyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢, though, is the fact that everyone Ã¢â‚¬â€œ press, fans, and weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re betting even some of the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s family Ã¢â‚¬â€œ will be hearing it for the very first time today. Aside from putting out Ã¢â‚¬ËœViolence (Enough Is Enough)Ã¢â‚¬â„¢ last December, thereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s been no leak, no pre-release stream, no 30-second teasers to soften the impact of these 53 minutes on first listen. And while we might all be caught up in this bubble of excitement right now, when it passes and weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ve all had some time to sit with it, one thing will still remain true: Ã¢â‚¬ËœCommon CourtesyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ is not the end of this band. If anything, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s their new beginning.

The law is a complicated thing, but listening to music is not. Listening to music is easy. So even though you might not be interested in learning the ins and outs of A Day To RememberÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s ongoing lawsuit with (former?) label Victory Records, you can instead digest something much more straightforward: The bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s new album, Common Courtesy. And in the face of two years of drama surrounding the release of this record, it seems like an important time to remind the Internet that years down the road, people wonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t remember that a band was once in a lawsuit with its label Ã¢â‚¬â€œ but the record, and these songs, will be remembered. The record lasts forever.

ThatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a good thing for A Day To Remember in this case. Common Courtesy is an easy step up from its predecessor, What Separates Me From You, and sees the Ocala, FL-based quintet continuing to become the best at what it does. Which is to say, play pop-punk interlaced with breakdowns interlaced with screamy mosh calls...whatever that genre is called. Is "easycore" a thing? Was it ever a thing? I donÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t really care.

Common Courtesy is an apt title for this album. Throughout its 13 songs and 54 minutes (!), vocalist Jeremy McKinnon chronicles the last three years of his bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s collective life. Actually, the lyrics quite often reminisce on the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s beginnings Ã¢â‚¬â€œ from the opening "City of Ocala" to the closing "I Remember," there isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t a shortage of tour stories or memories of the bandÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s early years. There is, of course, plenty of vitriol directed at Tony Brummel, who allowed this to be a thing, so yeah. Another theme on the record is demanding respect Ã¢â‚¬â€œ whether this is aimed at Victory Records directly or an army of "haters" or, whatever, maybe everyone in the universe, itÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s certainly something that is touched upon multiple times throughout Common Courtesy.

A Day To RememberÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s rise to success has been formulaic: Equal parts pop-punk, pop melody and screamy metalcore have been combined on every ADTR release so far and Common Courtesy doesnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t stray from that path. It does, however, see the band perfecting the genre that it basically created for itself Ã¢â‚¬â€œ the poppy parts are poppier, the heavy parts are heavier and the mosh calls are moshier. The riff in "Sometimes YouÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re The Hammer, Sometimes You're The Nail" is, like, totally head-bangy while tracks like "Best Of Me," "Life @ 11" (cÃ¢â‚¬â„¢mon with that title) and "I Surrender" are firmly placed into the "pop-punk" category of things and shine there. If you remove the breakdowns and screamy screams, A Day To Remember would actually be a pretty damn good pop-punk band, and for that reason, Common Courtesy is worth a spin even if youÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re not a metalcore fan.

ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a difficult thing for a reviewer to get his head out of his own ass and see the bigger picture sometimes. I really hate the Ã¢â‚¬Å“mosh callsÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ that this band prides itself on Ã¢â‚¬â€œ the "BRACE FOR IMPACT!!" roar in "Right Back At It Again" pretty much ruins that track for me and the "NO FUCKING RESPECT!" yell in "The Document Speaks For Itself" (truly a gem of a song title) pretty much accomplishes the same endgame. And minute-long breakdowns never really feel "necessary," do they? But, like, while weÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re talking about respect again, IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m pretty capable of seeing the bigger picture in this case: A Day To Remember is the biggest band in the world playing this genre of music and they have firmly planted their collective foot as being the best at it.

Every single fan of this band is going to eat this record up. TheyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢re going to listen to it for months on end without listening to anything else. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s going to be their album of the damn year. ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t any beautiful poetry to be found on this record, there isnÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t any revolutionary new musicianship and thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not the point. Maybe IÃ¢â‚¬â„¢m not going to spin this record constantly in my spare time so I can mosh in my living room...but disrespect A Day To Remember? After telling a record label with a documented history of treating its bands like shit to fuck off, and after releasing an album thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s going to help it continue its dominance in its genre? Disrespect a band after that? Not me. I hope you sell a zillion records and use that money to buy more horses in Ocala, A Day To Remember.

Even without releasing any new music in three years, ADTR is currently playing to arenas across the country. Their last two albums have sold half a million records combined in the United States. Kids buy stupid basketball shorts from them at every show. A Day To Remember is nothing if not a freight train of an entity. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a powerhouse. In "City," McKinnon sings, "This is our corner of the world," and while he's not actually talking about the genre in which his band resides, he might as well be. With Common Courtesy...love it or hate it as you will...A Day To Remember is getting started all over again. And the album ensures that this band hasn't yet seen the peak of its popularity.
